item.title: Item-Wise and Distribution-Wise Matching
item.description: “Words were controlled between conditions for frequency and length (all F values < 1).” How many times have you read a paper with a sentence like this in the Materials section? This is a problem because of: Statistical reasons: They’re assuming all kinds of things about their variables (e.g. that they’re all normally distributed), and more importantly, interpreting a non-significant p-value as evidence for equivalence. A small but “non-significant” difference in a confounding variable could have a very real and noticeable effect on an outcome when you repeat the same stimuli across hundreds of trials and many subjects.
